Back in April, when the possibility of Britain actually voting to leave the European Union seemed remote, two newspapers commissioned a poll asking which political figure readers would most like to dine with. Boris Johnson, who had recently announced his support for Brexit, was the winner by a wide margin: 38 percent of respondents said they'd prefer his company, compared with 18 percent for the Labour Party leader, Jeremy Corbyn.
Mr. Cameron, who had staked his political future on the vote, resigned.
